posts.cooked:
Hello, I have been working on using a pose estimator to update the pose of the robot with a limelight. I have gotten megatag 1 working, but the pose of the robot seems to oscillate around its actual pose. The megatag 2 pose seems much better in terms of stability of the pose, but the pose with megatag 2 is flipped so it’s on the opposite side of whatever tag it sees.

Google Drive file.

The other problem that I’m having with megatag 2 is that the robot sweeps across the field when I try to rotate, but the rotation with megatag 1 works fine. IMG_0630.mov - Google Drive . Here is the code. 5438chargersrobotics/2024-Code (github.com) Any ideas would be appreciated.

posts.name: Justin Chau
posts.cooked: I didn’t look into your code, but based on the behavior from the video, it looks like you are not passing the heading of the robot properly to MegaTag2.

posts.name: Carlos Salazar
posts.cooked: After a quick glance at your code, I think your implementation for MT2 looks great. My only concern is that you update your pose in both periodic() and updateOdometry() . There’s a possibility that you’re using both MT1 and MT2 simultaneously, which I imagine could create some weird behavior. This idea matches with your video in that your issues are most apparent where MT1 and MT2 should differ greatly in results.

posts.name: Matthew Milunic
posts.cooked:
Since MegaTag2 uses the robot rotation or heading passed into it as a reference for what direction it is looking, if your robot pose is appearing on the opposite side of tags that your robot actually is, there is a chance that the transform you have for your camera is 180° off from the one you have in the Limelight for the Yaw. This would basically result in your robot rotating 180° around the AprilTag when using MegaTag2, but only 180° around the center of your robot when using MegaTag1, so you may not have noticed it with MegaTag1. I would suggest trying to change your LLs internal Yaw by 180°.

Turning causing your pose to sweep around is likely being caused by this pose flipping happening around your AprilTags.

Also, looking in your code, you appear to be calling updateOdometry() and then updating the pose using MegaTag1 again. This would lead to you using both at the same time if you had MegaTag2 enabled and using MegaTag1 twice in the same periodic cycle if you didn’t have MegaTag2 enabled. I would suggest commenting out what is after updateOdometry() in your swerve periodic.

Hopefully this helps a bit!

I changed the Limelight’s yaw to 180 degrees, but then it showed the camera on the back of the robot instead of the front. I then changed the limelight forward from 0.4 meters to -0.4 meters and this fixed the problem. The pose with megatag 2 is now much more stable and accurate than megatag 1, and now we can more accurately shoot based on the distance to the speaker. Thank you for the help!

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
5348-Programmer:

yaw to 180 degrees

5348-Programmer:

forward … -0.4 meters

This is exactly right for defining a camera on the back of the robot.
